questions.text: Which of the following is the test used for antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ Minimal inhibitory concentration(MIC) : The lowest concentration of the antibiotic inhibits the pathogen's growth in the medium. Minimal bactericidal concentration(MBC) : The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.
  • ➤ Minimal inhibitory concentration(MIC) : The lowest concentration of the antibiotic inhibits the pathogen's growth in the medium.
  • ➤ Minimal inhibitory concentration(MIC)
  • ➤ Minimal bactericidal concentration(MBC) : The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.
  • ➤ Minimal bactericidal concentration(MBC)

Minimal Inhibitory Concentration (MIC)
  • The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits the growth of the pathogen in the medium.

Minimal Bactericidal Concentration (MBC)
  • The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.

Methods
  • Dilution method
  • Disc diffusion method
  • E-Test (combo of first two methods)
  • Automated methods

questions.text: Identify the media?
questions.explanation:
Culture Medium

Purpose/Property

Examples of Use

Nutrient Agar

General-purpose medium for routine culturing

Supports the growth of a wide range of microorganisms

Blood Agar

Differentiation of hemolytic bacteria

Detects hemolysis patterns (alpha, beta, gamma)

MacConkey Agar

Selective for gram-negative bacteria

Differentiates lactose-fermenting from non-lactose-fermenting

Sabouraud Agar

Selective for fungi

Isolates and cultures fungal species

Mannitol Salt Agar

Selective for staphylococci

Differentiates mannitol-fermenting from non-fermenting

Eosin Methylene Blue (EMB) Agar

Selective for gram-negative bacteria

Differentiates lactose-fermenting from non-lactose-fermenting, inhibits gram-positive bacteria

Thioglycollate Broth

Culturing anaerobic bacteria

Provides a reducing environment for anaerobic growth

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Fimbriae are thin, hair-like appendages found on the surface of many bacteria, primarily Gram-negative bacteria.

Structure

Fimbriae are composed of protein subunits called pilins. They are usually shorter and more numerous than flagella.

Types
  • Common (Type I) Fimbriae: Adhesive fimbriae that bind to mannose-containing receptors on host cells.
  • Sex Pili: Involved in bacterial conjugation and DNA transfer.

Functions
  • Adhesion: Fimbriae allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces, cells, and tissues, which is crucial for colonization and infection.
  • Biofilm Formation: Contribute to biofilm formation, protecting bacteria from environmental stresses.
  • Gene Transfer: Sex pili facilitates the transfer of genetic material between bacteria during conjugation, promoting genetic diversity and the spread of antibiotic resistance.
  • Motility: Usually not involved except Type IV Pili, particularly in Neisseria species, enabling a type of movement known as twitching motility.

Uses in Medicine
  • Target for Vaccines: Components of fimbriae can be used as antigens in vaccines to prevent bacterial infections.
  • Antimicrobial Targets: Inhibiting fimbrial function can prevent bacterial adhesion and biofilm formation, making it a potential target for new antibiotics.

Clinical Importance
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) use Type 1 fimbriae to adhere to the urinary tract, causing UTIs.
  • Respiratory Infections: Bacteria like Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) use fimbriae to adhere to the respiratory tract.
  • Gastrointestinal Infections: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) use fimbriae to adhere to the intestinal mucosa, causing diarrhea.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Uses Type IV pili for surface attachment and biofilm formation.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Uses fimbriae for attachment to mucosal surfaces in the genitourinary tract.

Laboratory Identification
  • Hemagglutination Assay: Detects Type 1 fimbriae by their ability to agglutinate red blood cells.
  • Electron Microscopy: Visualizes fimbriae on the surface of bacteria.
  • Pellicle Formation: Observing pellicle formation on liquid culture surfaces can indicate the presence of fimbriae.

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism Category A agent?
questions.explanation:
Category A

Category B

Category C

Priority

High-priority agents posing a risk to national security

Second highest priority

Third highest priority with emerging pathogens

The reason they are classified into the respective categories:
  • Easily disseminated in the environment
  • High mortality risk
  • Cause public panic and social disruption
  • Requires special action for public health preparedness
  • Moderately easy to disseminate.
  • Moderate morbidity risk.
  • Requires enhanced disease surveillance.
  • It can be engineered for mass dissemination in the future.
  • It has the potential for high mortality and morbidity.

Examples:
  • Bacillus anthracis - Anthrax (Option B)
  • Francisella tularensis - Tularemia
  • Clostridium botulinum - Botulism
  • Yersinia pestis - Bubonic plague
  • Ebola virus - Ebola hemorrhagic fever
  • Clostridium perfringens - epsilon toxin.
  • Cryptosporidium parvum.
  • Escherichia coli (O157:H7)
  • Shigella dysenteriae.
  • Salmonella.
  • Vibrio cholera.
  • Coxiella burnetii (Option C ruled out)
  • Brucella (Option D ruled out)
  • Hantavirus
  • MDR-tuberculosis
  • Nipah Virus (Option A ruled out)
  • Yellow fever
  • Tick-borne encephalitis /hemorrhagic fever

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli species?
questions.explanation:
Test

Result

Indole Production

E. coli is typically indole positive.

Methyl Red (MR) Test

E. coli shows a positive result.

Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test

E. coli is typically negative.

Citrate Utilization

E. coli usually does not utilize citrate (negative result).

Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Agar

Shows fermentation of glucose, lactose, and production of gas.

Urease Test

E. coli is urease negative.

questions.text: What level of biosafety containment is required for specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS-CoV-2?
When would you choose to utilize a sanitizer? Prior to conducting a patient examination Following a patient examination After coming into contact with the patient's environment On open wound
questions.explanation:
Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

Effectiveness of Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

  • Contains ethanol, isopropanol, or a mix
  • Effectiveness depends on alcohol type, concentration (60-95%), application technique, and consistency.
  • Ethanol is more effective against viruses, while propanol is better for bacteria.

WHO Definition and Composition
  • Hand sanitizers consist of alcohol (liquid, gel, or foam), excipients, humectants, and sometimes antimicrobial agents (e.g., chlorhexidine for prolonged protection).
  • Higher alcohol concentrations (above recommended levels) can be paradoxically less effective due to reduced protein denaturation.

Indications and Limitations
  • Effective against most bacteria, fungi, and enveloped viruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2, Ebola, Zika).
  • Less effective against protozoan oocysts, non-enveloped viruses (e.g., norovirus, poliovirus), and bacterial spores (e.g., Clostridioides difficile).
  • Ineffective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with certain pathogens.

Contraindications and Risks
  • Can cause skin reactions like dryness, irritation, contact dermatitis, and rarely urticaria.
  • Frequent use may lead to minor alcohol absorption, though considered safe.
  • Fire hazard due to flammability

WHO-Recommended Formulations
  • Ethanol-based (80%) - Ethanol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.
  • Isopropyl alcohol-based (75%) - Isopropyl alcohol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.

Proper Application Technique
  • Apply 2.4 mL sanitizer, rub thoroughly for 15-30 seconds until dry.
  • Some dispensers may not release adequate amounts; users should ensure sufficient application.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected and processed for examination. The specimen is labeled at different levels as I, II, III, and IV. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope.

Affinity maturation is a process that enhances the binding strength of antibodies to their specific antigen during an immune response. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for this process?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Process

Key Components

Initial B Cell Activation

1. Antigen Recognition:

  • B cell captures antigen via surface IgM/IgD
  • Antigen internalization

2. Antigen Processing:

  •  Processed into peptides
  •  Loaded onto MHC-II molecules
  • B cell receptor (BCR) (IgM and IgD)
  • Surface immunoglobulins
  • MHC-II molecules

B Cell-T Cell Interaction

1. Signal Generation:

  • Signal 1: Antigen presentation to TH cells
  • Signal 2: CD40-CD40L interaction
  • Signal 3: Cytokine stimulation

2. T Cell Help:

  • TH1: IFN-γ (IgG production)
  • TH2: IL-4 (IgE production)
  • TCR-MHC-II complex
  • CD40-CD40L
  • Cytokine receptors
  • Co-stimulatory molecules

B Cell Response

1. Germinal Center Formation:

  • B cell proliferation
  • Somatic hypermutation
  • Class switching

2. Differentiation:

  • Into plasma cells
  • Into memory B cells
  • Antibody production
  • Affinity maturation
  • Immunological memory

Outcomes

1. Immediate Response:

  • Antibody secretion
  • Different Ig classes based on cytokines

2. Long-term Response:

  • Memory formation
  • Enhanced secondary response
  • IgG, IgA, IgE production
  • High-affinity antibodies
  • Long-lived plasma cells
  • Memory B cells

questions.text: Which type of microscope can be used to detect the motility of the probable causative organism in a truck driver presenting with painless indurated genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity?
questions.explanation:
Specimen Collection
  • Lesion cleaned with gauze soaked in warm saline.
  • Margins gently scraped to abrade superficial epithelium.
  • Gentle pressure applied to the lesion base to collect exudate (prevent blood admixture).
  • Serum collected for serology; CSF for neurosyphilis.

Dark ground microscopy
  • Exudate collected and placed under a coverslip.
  • Examined with dark ground microscopy.
  • T. pallidum identified by slender, tightly coiled spiral structure showing slow movement.

Silver Impregnation Staining
  • Fontana’s method is used for staining smear films.
  • Levaditi’s method is preferred for tissue sections.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. Which enrichment medium is used to isolate the organism from the stool sample?
Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria.
Which of the following organisms is considered a strict anaerobe?
questions.explanation:
Classification

Gram-negative, Strict anaerobic, rod-shaped bacterium

Morphology

Small, pleomorphic Gram-negative rods

Habitat

Normal flora of the oral cavity, gastrointestinal tract, and female genital tract

Pathogenicity

Opportunistic pathogen, causes anaerobic infections

Clinical manifestation
  • Oral and dental infections (periodontal disease, abscesses)
  • Aspiration pneumonia
  • Lung abscess
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Otitis media
  • Gynecological infections (bacterial vaginosis, pelvic inflammatory disease)

Diagnosis
  • Gram stain (Gram-negative rods)
  • Anaerobic culture
  • MALDI-TOF
  • PCR-based tests

Colony Morphology

Black-pigmented colonies on blood agar (some species)

Treatment

Metronidazole, β-lactam + β-lactamase inhibitors, Clindamycin

Resistance

Resistant to aminoglycosides

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles is associated with destruction of bacteria and viruses?
Which of the following stains is used for the diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation:
Property

Fungi

Bacteria
  1. Cell Structure

Eukaryote

Prokaryote
  1. Cell Wall Composition

Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans

Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid
  1. Cytoplasmic Membrane

Sterols are present except in Pneumocystis carinii

Sterols are absent except in Mycoplasma
  1. Cytoplasmic Contents

Membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, ER)

Membrane-bound organelles absent
  1. Nucleus

True nucleus with nuclear membrane; paired chromosomes

No nucleus or nuclear membrane; single circular dsDNA chromosome
  1. Diameter

5 – 10 μm; may be > 100 μm

< 2 μm
  1. Morphology

Yeast: ovoid, round; Moulds: filamentous

Cocci, bacilli, some branching
  1. Spores

Both asexual and sexual for reproduction

Asexual (endospores) primarily for survival

questions.text: What microscopy technique is utilized to generate a high contrast image of transparent, viable bacteria?
Which is true about RT-PCR method?

options.label: D
options.text: DNA is first converted to RNA

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not as a sanitizer?
Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.explanation:
Types

Target

Features

Southern blotting

(Option A ruled out)

DNA sequences

It involves separating DNA fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using labelled probes to identify specific sequences

Northern blotting

RNA sequences

(Option B)

The process is similar to DNA blotting but focuses on RNA. (Option D ruled out)

Western blotting

(Option C ruled out)

Proteins

This technique specifically detects and analyses proteins in a complex mixture. It involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using specific antibodies to detect the proteins.

Eastern blotting

Post-translational modifications

It refers to specialised Western blotting techniques that detect specific post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation or glycosylation.

Southwestern blotting

DNA-binding proteins

Combines Southern and Western blotting elements to identify proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are sterilized by gamma radiation?
questions.explanation:
Ionising

Features:

  • High penetration power
  • Sporicidal action +
  • Known as Cold radiation (do not increase surface heat)
  • Examples: Gamma rays, X-rays, Cosmic rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters
  • Catgut sutures - Gamma (γ) rays

Non-ionising

Features:

  • Low penetration power
  • Only bactericidal action +
  • Examples: UV rays, infrared rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters

Mechanism of action
  • DNA damage by Dimer formation

Quality control agent

  • Bacillus pumilus

questions.text: ​Disposable pipette tips are sterilized by which of the following methods? a. Autoclave b. Hot air oven c. Microwave d. 70% ethanol
questions.explanation: Correct Option D

questions.text: Sporulation occurs in this phase of bacterial growth curve:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Stationary Phase:

Lag Phase

Log Phase

Stationary Phase

Dead Phase
  • No increase in the number of bacteria
  • Cell adaptation
  • Increase in size, enzymes and metabolite
  • The maximum size of bacteria is seen in end of the lag phase
  • Cell division
  • Smaller in size
  • Maximum metabolic activity
  • More susceptible to antibiotics
  • Some bacteria remain viable and some are dead
  • Bacterial growth ceases due to depletion of nutrients
  • Mnemonic STAB (STAT from stationary)
    • S in sporulation
    • T in Exo Toxin production
    • A in antibiotic production
    • B in Bacteriocin production
  • Antibiotic production happens in this phase
  • Decline phase
  • Cell death or involution

Lag Phase

Log Phase

Stationary Phase

Dead Phase
  • No increase in the number of bacteria
  • Cell adaptation
  • Increase in size, enzymes and metabolite
  • The maximum size of bacteria is seen in end of the lag phase
  • Cell division
  • Smaller in size
  • Maximum metabolic activity
  • More susceptible to antibiotics
  • Some bacteria remain viable and some are dead
  • Bacterial growth ceases due to depletion of nutrients
  • Mnemonic STAB (STAT from stationary)
    • S in sporulation
    • T in Exo Toxin production
    • A in antibiotic production
    • B in Bacteriocin production
  • Antibiotic production happens in this phase
  • Decline phase
  • Cell death or involution
